    • Constructor Detail

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal amount,
             java.util.Currency currency,
             java.math.RoundingMode roundingMode)
        Full constructor.
        Parameters:
        amount - is required, can be positive or negative. The number of decimals in the amount cannot exceed the maximum number of decimals for the given Currency. It's possible to create a Money object in terms of 'thousands of dollars', for instance. Such an amount would have a scale of -3.
        currency - is required.
        roundingMode - is required, must match a rounding style used by BigDecimal.

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal amount)
        Constructor taking only the money amount.

        The currency and rounding style both take default values.

        Parameters:
        amount - is required, can be positive or negative.

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal amount,
             java.util.Currency currency)
        Constructor taking the money amount and currency.

        The rounding style takes a default value.

        Parameters:
        amount - is required, can be positive or negative.
        currency - is required.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public static void init(java.util.Currency defaultCurrency,
                        java.math.RoundingMode defaultRounding)
        Set default values for currency and rounding style. Your application must call this method upon startup. This method should usually be called only once (upon startup).

        The recommended rounding style is RoundingMode.HALF_EVEN, also called banker's rounding; this rounding style introduces the least bias.

        Setting these defaults allow you to use the more terse constructors of this class, which are much more convenient.

        (In a servlet environment, each app has its own classloader. Calling this method in one app will never affect the operation of a second app running in the same servlet container. They are independent.)

      • sum

        public static Money sum(java.util.Collection<Money> moneys,
                        java.util.Currency currencyIfEmpty)
        Sum a collection of Money objects. Currencies must match. You are encouraged to use database summary functions whenever possible, instead of this method.
        Parameters:
        moneys - collection of Money objects, all of the same currency. If the collection is empty, then a zero value is returned.
        currencyIfEmpty - is used only when aMoneys is empty; that way, this method can return a zero amount in the desired currency.

      • eq

        public boolean eq(Money money)
        Equals (insensitive to scale).

        Return OK only if the amounts are equal. Currencies must match. This method is not synonymous with the equals method.

      • gt

        public boolean gt(Money money)

        Parameters:
        money - Obiekt Wartość pienieżna
        Returns:

      • times

        public Money times(int factor)
        Multiply this Money by an integral factor. The scale of the returned Money is equal to the scale of 'this' Money.

      • times

        public Money times(double factor)
        Multiply this Money by an non-integral factor (having a decimal point).

        The scale of the returned Money is equal to the scale of 'this' Money.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns getAmount().getPlainString() + space + getCurrency().getSymbol().

        The return value uses the runtime's default locale, and will not always be suitable for display to an end user.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object aThat)
        Like BigDecimal.equals(java.lang.Object), this equals method is also sensitive to scale. For example, 10 is not equal to 10.00 The eq(Money) method, on the other hand, is not sensitive to scale.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
